prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
In each of the seven science goals, we plan for CO(1-0) observations of groups of galaxies that can be observed with the same calibrators, i.e., they are within 10 degrees of each other and can be observed with the same spectral setup.
To make sure there is no retuning for galaxies within Science Goals with multiple galaxies, we set the recession velocity to zero and manually set up the spectral windows to cover the frequency range necessary to observe CO(1-0) in all the galaxies in the Science Goal.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity: For our CO(1-0) observations, we have selected galaxies that we expect to be molecular-gas rich, based on the stellar mass and optical color cuts. Based on radial profiles of the molecular gas density in similar nearby galaxies (Bigiel et al. 2008), we expect our sample to have molecular-dominated centers with molecular hydrogen surface density > 20 M_sun/pc^2 and to have molecular hydrogen surface density ~ 10 M_sun/pc^2 at 0.5 times the optical radius. With our selected rms = 0.054 K, we will reach a one-sigma uncertainty on the molecular hydrogen surface density of 2 M_sun/pc^2, assuming the typical line width for our sample of 200 km/s and a resolution of 1.294 km/s. This sensitivity will allow us to detect the centers of galaxies at SNR>10 and emission at 0.5 times the optical radius at SNR~5.
Imaging: Our selected resolution of 3.3'' provides 1-1.5 kpc resolution for our sample, which will allow us to search for local variations in molecular gas depletion time due to accretion and interactions. The largest angular structure that we aim to recover is emission on scales of about 0.5 times the optical radius (0.5*r_25 = 9 - 27.5'' for our sample). This is well matched to the maximum recoverable scale (23'') and the FOV (55'') offered by ALMA.
Correlator Setup: Each of the seven Science Goals contains groups of galaxies that can be observed with the same calibrators, i.e., they are within 10 degrees of each other and can be observed with the same spectral setup. To ensure that there is no retuning for galaxies within one Science Goal, we set the recession velocity to zero and manually set up the spectral windows. The correlator setup offers a bandwidth (937.5 MHz) that includes the CO(1-0) line for all galaxies in each Science Goal. The resolution (1.294 km/s) will allow us to highly sample the ~200 km/s line widths in the galaxies.
The technical justification is the same for all Science Goals and is described in detail in the technical justification section for the first Science Goal.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: In this science goal, we used two spectral windows such that both galaxies can be observed with the same spectral setup.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The technical justification is the same for all Science Goals and is described in detail in the technical justification section for the first Science Goal.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The molecular gas depletion time (i.e., the efficiency of converting molecular gas into stars) varies by a factor of 50 from nearby galaxies out to high-z submillimeter galaxies. To understand these variations in the context of galaxy formation and evolution via mergers and accretion, we must measure the molecular gas depletion time in galaxies with known environment. We propose to use ALMA to measure the molecular gas content at kpc-scale resolution in 33 molecule-rich galaxies selected from the volume-limited RESOLVE survey, which offers a unique database of environment information, including the dark matter halo mass and density of neighbors. With these CO(1-0) data, in combination with existing data to trace the star formation rate, we will carry out the first test for the environmental dependence on the kpc-scale molecular gas depletion time. We will search for the signatures of gas inflow caused by accretion and interactions, such as higher central concentrations of molecular gas and increased efficiency of converting molecular gas into stars in the centers of interacting galaxies. To carry out this study, we request a total of 9.6 hours with the ALMA 12-m array.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
